description: Scottish and Northern English from Old Norse skuggi, from Proto-Germanic *skuwwô (“shadow, reflection”). Cognate with Icelandic skuggi, Swedish skugga, Danish skygge, Old English sċūa, sċūwa (“a shade”).

entries.meaning: (Northern England, Scotland) A shelter, a sheltered place (especially on the side of a hill).
examples: We was jickering along  […]  under the scug o' the hill.
"Let's go scug-hunting" is a common phrase.  […]  a stick with a leaden head, used for knocking down birds and scugs (squirrels).

entries.meaning: (dated, slang) A lower-school or inferior boy.
examples: […]  before the lower school scugs got there, and pitched it in at Acropolis.

verbs.description: scug (third-person singular simple present scugs, present participle scugging, simple past and past participle scugged)

entries.meaning: (Northern England, Scotland, transitive) To shelter; to protect.
(Northern England, Scotland, intransitive) To hide; to take shelter.
